The city that turned around its murder rate in the so-called Boston Miracle is again seeing a rise in violence.
Much of it is gang-related.
And law enforcement officials complain it is difficult to prosecute those cases because of a growing problem, witness intimidation.
Courtrooms in Boston already have banned T-shirts that read, 'stop snitchin' and cell phones with cameras.
A new bill in the Massachusetts legislature goes a step further.
It would restrict criminal defense attorneys' access to grand jury evidence against their clients.
From WBUR in Boston, Monica Brady-Myerov reports.
MONICA BRADY-MYEROV reporting:
The bill, aimed at curbing gang violence, would create the state's first witness protection program, offering police details and temporary relocation to witnesses who fear testifying.
The bill would also withhold grand jury testimony from defense lawyers -- something law enforcement officials say will encourage more witnesses to testify.
SLICK RICK AND DOUG E.
FRESH: (Singing) But that's true.
That's why we never have no beef.
Woo.
Current law allows the defense to have a written transcript of the hearing to go over with the defendant.
The transcript includes a list of witnesses, what they said under oath, and their address.
(Soundbite of crowd)
When those grand jury notes hit the streets in a gang murder it's like a bomb goes off.
I've seen it many times.
Emmett Folgert is head of an anti-gang group, Dorchester Youth Collaborative.
He was recently at the state house, lobbying.
Gangs don't trust each other.
If they come out with their own notes, fellow gang members may not believe them.
But if they come up with an official document from the court, that can become a hit list, that can cause murders.
It's very different.
Daniel Conley is district attorney of Suffolk County, which includes Boston.
He says witness intimidation occurs in about 90 percent of the gun and gang cases his office prosecutes.
Conley remembers one case in which an entire housing project was flooded with witness testimony.
The grand jury minutes were tacked to the doors of the development.
So basically, think about it, everyone who walked through the doors, what's this?
Oh, geez, Johnny Jones is talking to the police about the murder that happened here last week.
And now Johnny Jones might as well put a bull's-eye on his back, right?
So I mean, this is why we think it's important that they not be disseminated to the wider public.
Conley says another district attorney told him about another case in which grand jury minutes were mailed out so everyone could see who was cooperating with police.
The word rat was written on the minutes.
The bill in the State House could restrict defense access to grand jury minutes entirely unless a judge rules otherwise.

Anne Goldbach, president of the Massachusetts Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers, says without giving their clients time to study who will be testifying against them and what they'll say, defendants can't help with their cases.
It absolutely ties our hands in terms of consulting with our client, knowing how to investigate a case, trying to prepare a defense.
We may have all the information, we may know who these people are, but it means nothing if our client can't consult with us.
They may say, oh, that person isn't telling the truth or that person has a motive to lie.
Witness intimidation is a problem nationwide.
A majority of states already block pretrial access to grand jury minutes in order to encourage witnesses to testify.
Massachusetts, Florida and Missouri are some of the exceptions.
Harvey Silverglade, a Boston-based criminal defense and civil liberties lawyer, says there's no reason to completely block the defense from grand jury testimony.

In federal cases, he points out, grand jury testimony remains secret unless a witness goes onto to testify at a trial, and the defense doesn't get the transcript until shortly before the witness appears in court.

And of course, there's no reason to not give out grand jury minutes at least the day before a witness takes the stand, as is the case in the federal system, because at that point, it's too late to engage in witness intimidation.
State legislative leaders are working on a final version of the bill for a vote in the next few weeks.
It will then go to Governor Mitt Romney who says he supports efforts to protect witnesses.
If the bill becomes law, the Massachusetts Criminal Defense Lawyers Association plans to mount a constitutional challenge.
For NPR News, I'm Monica Brady-Myerov in Boston.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Melissa Block.
And I'm Michele Norris.
The Bush administration wants to rewrite one of the country's major environmental rules.
Under the rule, groups that manage fisheries must rebuild depleted stocks of fish in a decade, no more.
The 10-year rule helped curb an overfishing crisis when it took effect in 1996.
Spokesmen for the National Marine Fisheries Service say the rule is now out of date and ineffective.
Environmental groups say that's not true, to put it mildly.
NPR's John Nielsen has more.
JOHN NIELSEN reporting:
The crisis that begat the 10-year recovery rule peaked in the early 1990s, when many of the country's best-known fisheries were collapsing.
Federal calls for sharp new limits on fishing had triggered ferocious opposition.
Tony DiLernia, director of maritime technology at Kingsborough Community College in New York, sat on one of the local councils in charge of setting catch limits.
Mr.

TONY DiLERNIA (Director of Maritime Technology, Kingsborough Community College): I remember state police escorts out of meeting rooms in the early '90s after having made decisions that fishermen disagreed with, chairs being thrown across rooms, threats to us--`If you do this, we're going to do this to you.
I remember that.
Meetings like those are partly why the regional councils often refused to limit fishing, even as many stocks were pushed to the brink of commercial extinction.
But that all changed in 1996 when Congress passed a law called the Sustainable Fisheries Act.
Under this law, when federal scientists ruled that a fishery was depleted, the regional councils were forced to do something about it.
And it also said that we had to do it over a finite time frame.
We couldn't just take forever to eliminate overfishing and rebuild the stocks.
Steve Murawski, chief scientist with the National Marine Fisheries Service, says the councils were given 10 years to rebuild most of the depleted stocks.
Short extensions to these deadlines were expressly prohibited.
Today it's clear that the 10-year rule has done a lot of good, says Murawski.
Fish like haddock, summer flounder and scup have bounced back dramatically.
Other fish have not done as well.

But if you look at the track record, particularly since 1996, we feel that we're on a positive trajectory with these stocks, and we've learned a great deal about the role of science and the role of hard targets in terms of the rates of fishing and our goals for stock rebuilding.
...Point guard...
Right.
Ironically, Murawski says one of the things he's learned is that the inflexibility that used to be the strength of this 10-year recovery rule has now become a weakness.

That's because while this law does not allow for short extensions, it does allow regional councils to go back to the drawing board and come up with whole new recovery plans, and that, in Murawski's opinion, has delayed conservation.
We've given an incentive to councils that if they wait long enough, we would extend that time frame to, say, up to 20 years.
Murawski's one of the authors of a plan to replace the 10-year rule.
It would force regional councils to step in quickly to limit overfishing, but recovery deadlines would be set on a case-by-case basis, and short extensions would be allowed.
It's fair to say that environmentalists hate this new proposal.
Carl Safina, director of the non-profit Blue Ocean Institute, says that's because it was this drop-dead deadline that made the old plan work.
Trying to stop overfishing without hard deadlines is like trying to control reckless driving without setting speed limits, he says.
You do need a number.
Otherwise, every time the cop pulls you over, he'll say, `You were going too fast,' and you'll say, `No, I wasn't going too fast.
And if there's no number to decide whether you were or you weren't, then you can just argue about it and get nothing done.
Safina fears a return to the bad old days of nasty public hearings and unheeded federal warnings.
But Tony DiLernia of Kingsborough Community College thinks those concerns are overblown, mostly because American fishermen are more willing to accept federal regulations than they used to be.
Mr.
DiLERNIA: The old guys that fished under no regulations, they're becoming dinosaurs and unfortunately we're dying.
And the guys who are coming into the industry came in understanding.
The proposal to erase the 10-year rule is open to public comment until the end of October.
Federal officials say they won't make a final decision until sometime next year.
John Nielsen, NPR News, Washington.
